alert.note: Alert for Monroe (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued January 14 at 12:24PM EST until January 14 at 1:30PM EST by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a * Snow Squall Warning for... Sussex County in northwestern New Jersey... Northern Warren County in northwestern New Jersey... Central Monroe County in northeastern Pennsylvania... * Until 130 PM EST. * At 1224 PM EST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from near Pecks Pond to near McMichael, moving east at 35 mph. HAZARD...Intense bursts of heavy snow and gusty winds leading to blowing snow and rapidly falling visibility. Wind gusts greater than 35 mph. SOURCE...Radar and webcams. IMPACT...Dangerous and life-threatening travel conditions are expected to develop rapidly in the warning area. This includes the following highways... Interstate 80 in Pennsylvania between mile markers 293 and 314. Interstate 80 in New Jersey between mile markers 0 and 1. Interstate 380 in Pennsylvania between mile markers 0 and 5. Locations impacted include... Newton, Montague, Mount Pocono, Hopatcong, East Stroudsburg, Blairstown, Franklin, Hamburg, Ogdensburg, Sussex, Branchville, Andover, High Point, Henryville, Lake Mohawk, Werry Lake, Greendell, Millbrook, Pocono Raceway, and Delaware Water Gap. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Consider avoiding or delaying travel until the snow squall passes your location. If you must travel, use extra caution and allow extra time. Rapid changes in visibility and slick road conditions may lead to accidents. Serious injuries and deaths may result from people exiting their vehicles during a snow squall. Drivers may not be able to see you or to stop! If stopped on the roadway or involved in an accident, quickly exit your vehicle move as far away from the roadway as possible ONLY when it is safe to do so. Do not stand along or near the roadway, since approaching vehicles may be unable to maintain control. SNOW SQUALL...OBSERVED SNOW SQUALL IMPACT...SIGNIFICANT
